Package com.bluegosling.choice

APIs for tagged union types.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    Choice<A,B>
    An object that represents a choice between one of a few options.
    Choice.OfFive<A,B,C,D,E>  
    Choice.OfFour<A,B,C,D>  
    Choice.OfThree<A,B,C>  
    Choice.OfTwo<A,B>
    Operations for a Choice that has exactly two options.
    Choice.Ops3<A,B,C>
    Extends the Choice interface with operations for choices with at least three options.
    Choice.Ops4<A,B,C,D>
    Extends the Choice interface with operations for choices with at least four options.
    Choice.Ops5<A,B,C,D,E>
    Extends the Choice interface with operations for choices with at least five options.
    Choice.VisitorOfFive<A,B,C,D,E,R>
    A visitor for a choice with five options.
    Choice.VisitorOfFour<A,B,C,D,R>
    A visitor for a choice with four options.
    Choice.VisitorOfThree<A,B,C,R>
    A visitor for a choice with three options.
    Choice.VisitorOfTwo<A,B,R>
    A visitor for a choice with two options.

Package com.bluegosling.choice Description

APIs for tagged union types. These types are also known as disjoint unions, discriminating unions, sum types, and variant types. They provide a type-safe and efficient way to implement this pattern in Java. Included are union types with between two and five (inclusive) components, of which only one may be present at any time. They are divided into two families of implementations:
  1. Either / Any: These types require that exactly one component be present and non-null. These are most similar to union types found often in functional languages, like Scala.
  2. Union: These types require that exactly one component be present, but null components are allowed. They are more like traditional union or variant types in that they do not place constraints on the values that may be present.
The two families of implementations differ in regards to whether null values are allowed, in much the same way that Optional differs from Reference.

All of the types herein extend from the main interface Choice.
